headline.seo: Neil Hope Dies at 35; ‘Degrassi’ Actor Whose Life Unraveled
headline.main: Neil Hope Is Dead at 35; Teenage Actor Whose Life Unraveled
headline.print_headline: Neil Hope, 35, Teenage Actor Whose Life Unraveled

docs.abstract: Neil Hope, troubled Canadian actor who grew up in the 1980s before an audience of millions as a star in a pair of gritty Canadian television dramas, was found dead at age 35 on Nov 25, 2007 in a boarding house in Hamilton, Ontario; Hope's family members found out about his death only recently, four years after the fact.
docs.snippet: Mr. Hope starred as a troubled teenager in the popular Canadian shows “Degrassi Junior High” and “Degrassi High” in the 1980s.

docs.lead_paragraph: During flu season in Bangladesh, mothers who got shots in their last trimester gave birth to babies almost seven ounces heavier on average.

headline.seo: Flu Shots for Expectant Mothers Add to Babies’ Birth Weight
headline.main: Flu: Flu Shots for Expectant Mothers Add to Babies’ Birth Weight
headline.print_headline: Flu: Vaccines for Women in the Last Trimester Add to Babies’ Birth Weight in Bangladesh

docs.abstract: Dr Mark C Steinhoff study in The Canadian Medical Association Journal finds that third-trimester flu shots given to pregnant women in Bangladesh appeared to increase the birth weights of their babies, making infants' survival more likely.
docs.snippet: During flu season in Bangladesh, mothers who got shots in their last trimester gave birth to babies almost seven ounces heavier on average.

docs.lead_paragraph: After decades of sloppy research, bad publicity, lawsuits and widespread fears of health hazards, the intrauterine device is making a major comeback in the United States. Although the IUD has long been the most popular reversible form of contraception worldwide, use of the device in this country, where oral contraceptives have always been far more popular, has lagged far behind that in other industrialized nations.

headline.main: Personal Health: Americans Get Reacquainted With IUDs

docs.lead_paragraph: Neil Hope grew up in the 1980s before an audience of millions as a star in a pair of gritty Canadian television dramas, ''Degrassi Junior High'' and its sequel, ''Degrassi High.'' The shows were cultural touchstones in Canada and cult favorites in the United States, where they anticipated teenage docudramas like MTV's ''Real World'' and soaps like ''Beverly Hills, 90210.'' Mr. Hope had few secrets left after his five years in the role of the troubled teenage character Derek (Wheels) Wheeler. The show's producers admitted all along that the story of Wheels, a boy who stumbles through misfortunes before drifting into alcoholism, drew broadly on the life of Mr. Hope, who never had formal acting training.

docs.lead_paragraph: Framing a pre-abortion ultrasound as empowering information, or as a violation of a woman’s dignity.

headline.seo: Ultrasound: A Pawn in the Abortion Wars
headline.main: Ultrasound: A Pawn in the Abortion Wars
headline.print_headline: Ultrasound: A Pawn in the Abortion Wars

docs.abstract: News analysis; debate over legislation in Virginia that would require a woman seeking an abortion to first have an ultrasound ended up revolving around the nature of the ultrasound, with anti-abortion forces trying to define it as something benign while their opponents successfully cast it in the most ominous terms; crucial to the fight is the belief among abortion opponents that viewing an ultrasound will help convince pregnant women not to undergo an abortion, which is unsupported by clinical studies.
docs.snippet: Framing a pre-abortion ultrasound as empowering information, or as a violation of a woman’s dignity.

docs.lead_paragraph: Too bad Mitt Romney doesn’t have the Weinstein Company as his super PAC. He might be closer to the nomination.
docs.abstract: Frank Bruni Op-Ed column draws parallels between the lobbying that film executives engage in so that their companies' films win Oscars and the campaigning being done by Republican presidential candidates.

docs.lead_paragraph: A child is born — against the odds — to Americans in a Muslim land.

headline.seo: A Gift From Allah — Modern Love

docs.abstract: Rachel Pieh Jones Modern Love column describes her anxiety over giving birth while living in Djibouti, a small Muslim country in Africa with high mortality rates for both mothers and babies.
